question: Which of the following is a first-generation Cephalosporin used for surgical prophylaxis?
exp: First-Generation Cephalosporins: include - Cefazolin, Cephalexin, Cephradine, Cefadroxil, Cephalothin and Cephapirin Cefazolin is good for skin preparation as it is active against skin infections from S. pyogenes and MRSA. It is administered Intramuscular or Intravenous (i. e Parenteral drug). It is a drug of choice for surgical prophylaxis. Cefazolin does not penetrate the CNS and cannot be used to treat meningitis. Cefazolin is better tolerated than Antistaphylococcal Penicillins, and it has been shown to be effective for serious Staphylococcal infections e. g Bacteremia. Oral First generation drugs may be used for the treatment of urinary tract infections and Staphylococcal or Streptococcal infections, including cellulitis or soft tissue abscess.

question: A patient needs antibiotic treatment for aificial valve, culture-positive infective enterococcal endocarditis. His medical history includes severe anaphylactic reaction to penicillin G during the past year. The best approach would be treatment with:

question: Which is not a bacterial drug resistance mechanism?
exp: Resistance to antibiotics occurs by following mechanism. By synthesizing enzymes against antibiotics: Penicillinases, Beta lactamases, Aminoglycoside inactivating enzymes. By altering porin channels, so the drug is not able to enter inside. Resistance to aminoglycosides occurs by this mechanism. By actively effluxing the drug out of the cell: resistance to tetracyclines occurs by this mechanism. Inhibition of DNA gyrase or topoisomerase activity is mechanism of action of flouroquinolones rather than mechanism of acquisition of resistance. So, answer is 'D'.
opc: By actively effluxing the drug out of the cell
opd: By inhibiting DNA gyrase or topoisomerase activity

question: Which of the following is not bacteriostatic:-

question: A 36 years old woman recently treated for leukemia is admitted to the hospital with malaise, chills and high fever. Gram stain of blood reveals the presence of gram negative bacilli. The initial diagnosis is bacteremia and parenteral antibiotics are indicated. The record of the patient reveals that she had severe uicarial rash, hypotension and respiratory difficulty after oral pencillin V about 6 months ago. The most appropriate drug should be:
exp: In patient with severe sensitivity to penicillin, all beta lactams except monobactams are contraindicated. Both Aztreonam and imipenem are effective for gram negative infections but as the patient is allergic to beta lactams (carbapenems show cross allergy), Aztreonam is preferred in such a patient.

question: Drug of choice for Clostridium difficile infection is
exp: Drugs used for Clostridium difficile infection are DOC is oral Vancomycin Alternatives are metronidazole and fidoxamicin Monoclonal antibody against Clostridium toxin is bezlotoxumab.

question: Colistin is not active against?
exp: Colistin* It was obtained from B. colistinus.* It is active against gram-negative bacteria only; all except Proteus, Serratia and Neisseria are inhibited. * It is more potent on Pseudomonas, Salmonella and Shigella. Mechanism of action Rapidly acting bactericidal agent having a detergent-like action on the cell membrane. They have high affinity for phospholipids. It causes membrane distoion or pseudopore formation. It may also inactivate the bacterial endotoxin.

question: Anterior nares is the most common site of colonization in carrier state of MRSA. What is the best treatment?
exp: Anterior nares are the MC site of colonization in the carrier state of MRSA. Mupirocin (2% topical cream) is DOC for MRSA carriers. Another drug that can be used is topical Bacitracin. Vancomycin is an intravenous DOC for treatment of severe infections caused by MRSA. Colistin (cell membrane inhibitor) is DOC for Superbug (bacteria mostly Klebsiella producing New Delhi Metallo-beta-lactamase). Cefazolin is first generation Cephalosporin.

question: Dose and duration of benzathine penicillin G for prophylaxis of rheumatic fever is:-
exp: Drug of choice for secondary prophylaxis of rheumatic fever (RF) is Benzathine penicillin G. It is given intramuscular every 4 weeks. Duration of prophylaxis Category Duration of prophylaxis RF without carditis For 5 years after the last episode or till 21 years of age (whichever is longer) RF with carditis but without valvular disease For 10 years after the last episode or till 21 years of age (whichever is longer) RF with valvular disease For 10 years after the last episode or till 40 years of age (whichever is longer); sometimes life-long

question: Treatment of choice for late cardiovascular syphilis is?
exp: Treatment of choice for late cardiovascular syphilis: Benzathine penicillin 7. 2 million units in three divided doses, once a week. Benzathine penicillin G, 2. 4 million units intramuscularly once a week for 1-3 weeks, is effective in the treatment of syphilis.
opa: Benzathine penicillin 7. 2 million units in three divided doses
opb: Benzathine penicillin 2. 4 million units single dose

question: The drug that should be used for prophylaxis of close contacts of a patient suffering from meningococcal meningitis is:
exp: - Rifampicin, ceftriaxone and ciprofloxacin are used for the prophylaxis of meningococcal meningitis. - Ceftriaxone is most effective drug for prophylaxis of meningococcal meningitis, however it is injectable drug. - Resistance to rifampicin has been repoed in many meningococci, so it is not preferred these days. - The drug of choice for prophylaxis of meningococcal meningitis should be chosen as Ciprofloxacin > Rifampicin > Ceftriaxone

question: Clostridium difficile diarrhoea is most commonly associated with
exp: Clostridium difficile diarrhea is a super-infection also called Pseudomembranous colitis. Mc cause is 3rd generation Cephalosporins Other causes include Clindamycin, Aminopenicillins (Ampicillin and Amoxycillin), and Fluoroquinolones. DOC for treatment of PMC is oral Vancomycin now. Stool transplant can also be done. MAB against toxin of C. difficile: Bezlotoxumab.

question: The penicillin G preparation with the longest duration
exp: Penicillin G due to it's rapid tubular secretion, it is very sho acting. It's duration of action is increased with probenecid which compete with penicillin at tubular pump. Procaine penicillin G and benzathine penicillin G are administered IM and serve as depot forms. They are slowly absorbed into the circulation and persist at low levels over a long time period. Specially Benzathine penicillin G has longest duration of action. Penicillin G are not effective orally as it is acid labile. Penicillin which are acid stable are: - V: Penicillin V- O: Ofloxacillin- D: Dicloxacillin- K: Cloxacillin- A: Amoxicilin/Ampicillin

question: Which of the following is not an established antimicrobial drug synergism at clinical level?
exp: Combination of a bacteriostatic and a bactericidal drug in most cases is antagonistic. Bactericidal drugs act on fast multiplying organisms whereas bacteriostatic drugs inhibit the growth. Here, penicillins are bactericidal whereas tetracyclines are bacteriostatic.
opa: Amphotericin B and flucytosine in cryptococcal meningitis
opb: Carbenicillin and gentamicin in pseudomonal infections
opc: Penicillin and tetracycline in bacterial meningitis
opd: Trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole in coliform infections
